reviewText: Got an email from Amazon asking me to review my purchase and the note encouraged me to be the first reviewer.  Since I never back down from a challenge, I took Amazon up on their offer.I think Joe will sound awesome.I think Beth will too.I also think they will have great moments of interplay and Beth will be fun to watch as she works the audience.I think that both the picture quality and sound quality will be superb.I think the neighbors will complain after I crank this up to 11.I think you'll love this too.Thanks!

reviewText: Those familiar with Joe B's "Live from Beacon Theatre" on disc might remember Beth Hart who comes out and does a couple numbers with Joe and wows the crowd.  She gets full-on headliner treatment here with Joe and some of his usual companions backing her up.  Joe get plenty of licks in, but make no mistake, this is Ms. Hart's show.  And she won't let you down.Hart is at her best when she takes on smoldering songs like "Close To My Fire" which really got my attention.  Ron Dziubla's sexy bass sax helps as well.  Melody Gardot's "Your Heart is as Black as Night" is another sultry show stopper, and seemed very personal from Hart's delivery.  Hart mentions Billy Holliday and drummer Anton Fig before she just kills "Baddest Blues."  Another well sung song is the sad "Strange Fruit" made famous by Nina Simone.  Bonamassa is at his best here with a beautiful lead-in and finishes with a mournful, dynamic solo.  Whew!  I also liked "If I Tell You I Love You," another Gardot song which Hart plays with as a French cabaret singer.There's little fault to be found but I thought some of the mood changing songs ("Chocolate Jesus," "See Saw" and "Nutbush City Limits") just seemed extrinsic.  Overall this is a near perfect concert, especially if you love the blues.  Hart and Bonamassa are a perfect match.The Blu ray disc comes with a 1080p resolution and a 1.78:1 aspect ratio.  Like most concerts, it is film in relative low light but the camera does a good job with the detail and color.  I could actually read the brand name of Joe's watch.  The audio is DTS-HD Master Audio 5.1 and is likewise well done.  He horn section appears on the right and when they are featured, show up in the right surround channel.  Other instruments are properly aligned as well.  Well done.  Extras include "The Making of: Live in Amsterdam," another take of "Someday After Awhile," a photo collection and other short piece called "Up, Down, All Around: Behind The See Saw."  The set list is noted in Amazon's description.
summary: (BLU RAY REVIEW) 4 1/2 stars for a great Blues pairing

reviewText: Great music and musicianship; however, I found the performance almost unwatchable.  it's not just Beth's shaking and shimmying on stage during extended instrumental solos.  Take note of how many times the musicians appear to be playing to and smiling at the camera -- not the audience.  The visuals on the whole have a contrived feel and do not capture the "live experience" to the same extent as the two Royal Albert performances and the Beacon Theater concerts.
summary: Hi Def Mastering Top-Notch but fails to capture the ambience of the live show

reviewText: I picked up the Blu-Ray of Beth Hart & Joe Bonamassa Live in Amsterdam at Joe’s concert last Friday.  I am a huge fan of both artists, and I have both of their studio collaboration albums.  The short version of the review is that fans of their studio work with absolutely dig this.  If this is you, stop reading.  Put it in your cart and make the purchase.Those of you still with me want a little more detail.  The concert on the DVD is one of five nights that Beth, Joe, and their amazing band played in Europe last year.  If you have Joe’s Tour de Force collection, you will be familiar with the rest of the musicians (except for Blondie Chapman on Rhythm Guitar, all of these cats appeared on at least one of the Tour de Force shows).  The performances are all top notch including Anton Fig on Drums, Arlan Shierbaum on Keys, and Carmine Rojas on Bass.  Lee Thornburg leads a great three-piece horn section to round things out.  Shierbaum reprises his bit from the Hammersmith Apollo show where he climbs up on top of his organ during one of his solos.  The horn section often dances when they are not playing.  There is plenty to see while you listen to the amazing music.  In total, the show is just under two hours long, and they hit most of the songs from the two studio albums.  The two items not from the studio recordings are Joe’s one lead vocal track “Someday After Awhile You’ll Be Sorry” and “Baddest Blues” from Beth’s last solo album.  It is all great stuff.But wait!  There’s more.  There are two lengthy bonus features with behind the scenes and interviews.  I loved these because it gives a glimpse of who these master musicians are.  It makes the experience much more personal than just watching the concert.  Whereas the Tour de Force bonus features were about Joe, these features are about how Joe yielded center stage to “one of the most undiscovered singers” in Beth Hart.  In turn, you hear Beth talk about how touched she was when she saw that her name was first on the mock-up for their first album cover.  I was a huge fan before, but Beth and Joe are rising toward the top of my favorite artists of all time.  In addition, there is a video from one of the other shows for “Someday After Awhile You’ll Be Sorry”.  It features interesting split screen views showing multiple musicians at the same time.  Finally, there is a slideshow of photos that lasts about four or five minutes.  It adds up to the geek fan’s dream.  This is the apex (for now) of the Beth Hart and Joe Bonamassa collaboration.  Buy it.  Watch it.  Repeat.  You won’t be sorry.
Title: N/A

reviewText: For me Joe Bonamassa isn't the guitar God he is to so many, I like him a lot, but I can't elevate him to Gary Moore status... but I'm getting off subject. What I do love about Joe is that he is adventurous , he is a super talented young man with the keys to the candy store and tries exciting projects and films them for those of us not lucky enough to be in the small live audience.  Just like his previous series of releases for his Tour De Force, this concert is filmed and presented as well as any hundred million dollar Hollywood motion picture, its just class and all of it first!  The bonus features are also heavy and there is a luxurious booklet that comes with it.  These are things major studios all skip to make more profit!Now lets get to the program.  Joe's singing is his biggest blind spot for me in his talent arsenal, and this is obvious when he has a guest like Paul Rodgers sing and Joe just plays... so when Joe decided to work with Beth Hart I was thrilled.  I've been one of the few fans of hers in the US for many many years and even have a copy of one of her DVDs in PAL because it's not available over here.  As Beth says, this isn't her doing her show (she is a fabulous songwriter and performer) it is her being an R&B; diva much like Tina Turner and Joe assuming the role of axeman band leader ala Ike Turner (with more chops to be sure).  The end result is true music, not computer manufactured sampled garbage, but fabulous singing, playing and goodness.... I wish young people would watch this and see what they are missing today!If you like great , real , organic music.... Rock n Roll, Blues, Swing, R&B; all mixed into a magical night..... order now!  Goodness knows I can't imagine Walmart or Target carrying this and where else can you buy music anymore?HIGHEST RATING.... highly recommended, first class from performance to presentation.
summary: anything less than 5 stars gives ME the Blues!

reviewText: Is there anything this guy touches that doesn't turn to gold? There just aren't enough accolades to go around. JB just might be the best rock and roll blues guitarist alive today. And Beth Hart...holy smoking hot sultry voice and performance. She is outstanding here. The band is tight and the songs showcase both of their abilities.Quality wise it doesn't get much better. As usual for JB the sound and video are fantastic. HD audio gets 4.75 stars. Just a smidge low on Beth's voice for the first few tracks but really I'm stretching looking for anything wrong.Stellar!

reviewText: It takes a powerful voice to complement Joe's powerful guitar and Beth handles this beautifully.  Starting with the sparkling, bubbling, fun, up-beat "Them There Eyes", the tone is set for the amazing roller coaster ride of this concert.  With this song, Beth captivates with singing a line and then Joe answering with his guitar - making it seem like a conversation.  The band gets really rocking on "Can't let Go" with Joe brilliantly playing the slide guitar making it one of the highlights of this DVD.  Beth's intro into "Close To My Fire" is right on for the sexy, smoldering lyrics of this song with Joe's guitar carrying on the smoldering feel.  Beth brings it down a notch sitting on the stage, drawing the audience in to "Your Heart Is As Black As Night" making it seem like a confessional of heartbreak with her insight into the relationship.  But when the piano comes out, you know you're in for a treat with Beth playing the piano and "Chocolate Jesus" does not disappoint with its carnival feel.  Her take on this song is so perfectly in tune with her style and Joe's guitar just seems to reverberate within the song (how does he do that?)  "Baddest Blues" - this is the Beth I absolutely love - vulnerable, emotional, gut-wrenching, but uplifting at the same time.  The band in the background electrifies her performance to making this the best performance of this song I have ever heard her do and it is worth the whole of the DVD.  Then, Joe belting out "Someday After Awhile (You'll Be Sorry)" with such passion you feel emotionally drained when the song is finished - he puts so much emotion in the song and we actually get two renditions - one on the main DVD and one on the bonus DVD. Absolutely loved this performance, Joe at his ultimate best (and Blondie was great too).  The most captivating song on the DVD is "Strange Fruit".  Joe's haunting, eerie, wailing, sobbing guitar is a lesson in understatement matching Beth's sensitive delivery of the song and Joe's guitar at the end is chilling. "Miss Lady", "I Love You More Than You'll Ever Know" and "Nutbush City Limits" just reinforces the fact that Beth can sing any song and make it her own with soaring vocals that are stunning.  Closing the concert with "I'd Rather Go Blind" made me cry - so sad.  Also, I want to note that this whole band contributes to the total excellence of this concert and without each and every one of them, the concert would be less.I love that Beth, in interviews, talks about her insecurities and how things are hard for her.  It makes her so much more relatable as her voice puts her in a league of her own.  This DVD is for anyone who wants to see the greatest guitarist in the world and one of the greatest singers on the same stage sharing their passions, their emotions and their tremendous talent with the world.

reviewText: These two perform well together, just no way around it. Beth Hart has an awesome voice that just grabs you and won't let go. Joe Bonamassa plays backup to her without overshadowing her but shines with his own brilliance at the appropriate time. A very good selection of songs that aren't so popular that everyone's done them and it seems too familiar but not so obscure you've never heard them before.
